Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Photoelectronic Properties of DNA-Chromophore Hybrids and Porphyrin Nanowires
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1306170 PI: Smith, Walter ORG: Haverford College

Title: RUI: Photoelectronic properties of DNA-chromophore hybrids and porphyrin nanowires

Technical: Self-assembled molecular circuits hold the promise of dramatic reductions in manufacturing and energy costs compared to conventional lithographic techniques, as well as the possibility of completely new functionalities. Creation of complex self-assembled circuits requires an easily programmable and sophisticated recognition capability; this can be provided by DNA. For electronic devices, the DNA must conduct charge. However, for distances longer than 50 nm, the conductivity of DNA is poor, especially in the dry state. In this work, methods for increasing the conductivity of DNA will be explored and characterized. The specific objectives of this work are: (1) Investigate methods of imparting long-range conductivity or photoconductivity to DNA by forming DNA/chromophore hybrids of two types, one with porphyrins intercalated into the base stack and one using modified bases that absorb in the near UV. (2) Refine techniques for selectively attaching the DNA/chromophore hybrids to specific electrodes, a requirement for the development of complex circuits. (3) Test predictions of a model for the photoelectronic properties of porphyrin-containing self-assembled nanowires, using 4-probe measurements, measurements under ultrahigh vacuum and variable O2 concentration, and measurements using circularly-polarized light. (4) Develop methods of creating three-terminal junctions in the DNA-chromophore hybrids, and also test for cross-talk between crossing hybrid strands. The work also focuses on nanowires self-assembled solely from porphryin molecules. These may have applications in molecular electronics, including light harvesting. Furthermore, probing the porphryin nanowires can give important insights about fundamental mechanisms in the DNA/chromophore hybrids.

Non-Technical: The results of this work will help to lay the foundations for an eventual true revolution in self-assembled molecular electronics. This field is at the stage where a deeper understanding of the basic science is needed to make progress. This work will provide pioneering insights into the physics of conductivity (as opposed to transfer of single charges) in DNA-chromophore hybrids. This research will include the first measurements of the effects of circularly polarized light on the photoelectronic properties of a self-assembled nanofilament. Results from this work will motivate researchers in physics, physical chemistry, and biophysics. Fifteen undergraduates and three high-school students will get an intense, cutting-edge research experience, including training in careful scientific practice as well as subfield-specific training. About 40% of these will be from groups underrepresented in physics (women, African-Americans, and Latinos). Each student will create a web page including a video interview to present his/her research to the general public. The PI will use his experience from mentoring 79 undergraduate research students to create a website/wiki devoted to mentoring physics undergraduate researchers, with sections devoted to each subdiscipline of physics. The PI will host the condensed matter portion of the website, will recruit other faculty to host the other sections, and will publicize the site by methods including annual contacts with all coordinators of physics 'Research Experience for Undergraduates' programs. This website will be consulted by many research mentors each year, and will provide at least a 10% improvement in the research efficiency of their students, corresponding to thousands of work hours for all the students put together in a single year. Further, the habits instilled in these students should persist through graduate school and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant centered self-assembling electronics. The goal of this field is to create circuits that assemble themselves from liquid solution. This will be achieved by careful design of the molecules, and application of assembly cues, such as electricity and changes in acidity. Self-assembly offers the promise of creating vast numbers (far more than quintillions) of circuits from a few liters of solution, of making circuits with brain-like three-dimensional connectivity, of assembly only at specified locations (perhaps within the body), of circuits with fundamentally new capacities, and of enabling and diversifying creative potential by making nano-scale circuit construction available at dramatically lower costs.

The field is still in its infancy; researchers are investigating wires and single transistors. We need to understand the fundamental physics of how electricity travels through self-assembled structures, how it can be controlled, and how to guide the assembly to create complex structures.

The structures we studied were made, at least in part, from porphyrin molecules. There are many porphyrins, all of which strongly absorb light; examples include chlorophyll and hemoglobin.

Prior to this grant, we were the first to investigate electronic properties of nanowires self-assembled from organic molecules. We showed that a particular porphyrin, TPPS4, assembles into nanowires that are photoconductive, meaning that they only conduct electricity when illuminated. This could have applications in which circuit function is changed by illuminating with a new light pattern. We introduced a qualitative model explaining how the photoconductivity occurs, and how these nanowires could be used to make transistors.

Under this grant, we continued to explore the properties of nanowires made from porphyrins, as described below, gaining important physics insights. However, there is no apparent way to guide assembly of these nanowires into complex circuits.

In contrast, the design of nanostructures created from DNA can be controlled by choosing the sequence of the bases (A, C, T, and G) that encode the genetic information, and taking advantage of the capability of one strand of DNA to selectively bind only to the strand with the matching base sequence. In principle, by adding short DNA strands in the correct order to a solution, and also by adding metal beads coated with appropriate DNA strands, we could build up controlled yet complex nanocircuits (figure 1).

However, DNA is a poor electrical conductor for lengths greater than several billionths of a meter. Furthermore, it does not absorb visible light, so it is not photoconductive. It does absorb ultraviolet light, but only UVB, which is destructive to DNA. Therefore, we investigated two ways of modifying DNA, so that it would absorb either visible or UVA light and become photoconductive. In the most successful method, we formed a complex of the DNA with the porphyrin TMPyP. We demonstrated that raising the humidity around these complexes induces photoconductivity that persists for several days after the humidity is lowered (figure 2).

We conducted many experiments on the TPPS4 nanowires, e,g, figure 3. At the time shown by the arrow, we began bombardment with hydrogen ions, resulting in the dramatic increase in photoconductivity shown. We also found that the action of transistors made from these nanowires is strikingly different depending on whether they are in a nitrogen or a hydrogen atmosphere (figure 4). The ?gate voltage? is the control that regulates the flow of current in a conventional transistor; these transistors show more complex behavior.

We also experimented with nanowires made from the porphyrin, CP1. These are the first photoconductivity experiments on nanowires made from a porphyrin with a ?handedness?; like your right hand, CP1 would look different if viewed in a mirror. We found that these nanowires are photoconductive (figure 5). When oxygen is added to the atmosphere, the photoconductivity increases, opposite the behavior of TPPS4 nanowires. To analyze these results, we made our model much more quantitative. This led to a significant prediction about the connection between photoconductivity and sensitivity to atmospheric gases for nanowires made from organic molecules.

An explicit goal was the mentoring of high school students and undergraduates. Four high school students and 30 undergraduates participated in this research, and received intense research and career mentoring. Thirteen were women, two were Hispanic, and one African American; all three groups are underrepresented in physics. Of the 25 who have already graduated, 72% went on to graduate school, a rate far higher than typical for our majors. An additional 16% went directly into STEM careers in industry.

Our research efforts were used synergetically to create two series of YouTube videos about what it?s like to do interdisciplinary science research. These give high school and beginning college students a realistic picture, to inspire and to aid in career planning. We also developed two websites to improve mentoring of undergraduate researchers and their research experience. These web resources are available at https://tinyurl.com/unxbrwj
